inference:
Subtracting the first equation from the second, we get

\begin{align*}
2^{x+2}+3^{y+1} - (2^x+3^y)&=18-5\\
\Rightarrow 2^{x+2}-2^x +3^{y+1}-3^y &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x(2^2-1)+3^y(3-1) &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x(3)+3^y(2) &=13\\
\Rightarrow 6\cdot2^x+6\cdot3^y &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x+3^y &=13/6.
\end{align*}

Since $2^x+3^y=5$, we have

$$13/6=5\Rightarrow 13=30\Rightarrow\text{contradiction}.$$

Final Answer: \boxed{$\text{No Solution}$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Let $2^x=a$ and $3^y=b$.  Since $2^{x+2}=2^2(2^x)$ and $3^{y+1}=3(3^y)$, the equations become

\begin{align*}
a+b&=5,\\
4a+3b&=18.
\end{align*}Multiplying the first equation by $3$ and subtracting it from the second equation, we find $a=\boxed{3}$ and $b = 2$.  Plugging these into the original equations, we find this works.

\begin{align*}
2^{x+2}+3^{y+1} - (2^x+3^y)&=18-5\\
\Rightarrow 2^{x+2}-2^x +3^{y+1}-3^y &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x(2^2-1)+3^y(3-1) &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x(3)+3^y(2) &=13\\
\Rightarrow 6\cdot2^x+6\cdot3^y &=13\\
\Rightarrow 2^x+3^y &=13/6.
\end{align*}

Since $2^x+3^y=5$, we have

$$13/6=5\Rightarrow 13=30\Rightarrow\text{contradiction}.$$
